article: It was in the autumn that I saw the longhaired sitting at the end of the station. Her eyes _ with a special good _ and trust. She was _ ."Hi," I said. She came over, _ her tongue over my hand carefully, _ herself to be scratched for a time, waved her tail and lay down again. I remembered thinking there are times God puts a _ in front of you. I took the dog. She was _ when she understood the news, _ up to kiss my face. To get her home safely, I had to _ her like a baby. She lay in my arms, eyes calmly _ on mine as if to say, "Hey, this is a nice idea. Why didn't you think of it before?' I named the dog Elizabeth. Height: about 30 inches. Weight: 35 pounds. Eyes: brown. Tongue: rich. She never barked. In 14 years, I heard her voice no more than three times. At night Liz and I stayed up _ dawn , watching TV. She liked _ than to sit at my _ .  After a while, my place became a dog's room. She kept herself _ . She also ran away at times . If you opened a door or window, she was out of it. It was a good thing I lived on the _ floor.  Liz loved to run, that was it. I would take her to a _ sports ground, and she would run at full speed. Then I'd _ her in the back of the car, _ she'd sleep. It was a dog's, too.
